title: Abuse in Plain Sight: How Bureaucrats Are Misusing Food Stamp Exemptions to Hide Their Errors
content:
No-good-cause exemptions are widely used to circumvent work requirements

There are currently 41 million Americans trapped in the cycle of dependency on the food stamp program—all while nearly nine million jobs remain open.1-2 States should be looking for ways to help get the millions of able-bodied adults on food stamps back to work, but unfortunately, in many states, the opposite is happening. Bureaucrats use waivers and exemptions far too often to excuse countless able-bodied adults from having to comply with food stamp work requirements.

One of these mechanisms is “no-good-cause exemptions,” also known as “discretionary exemptions” or “eight percent exemptions.” States can use these exemptions to excuse up to eight percent of their able-bodied adults without dependents (ABAWDs) from work requirements for any reason whatsoever.3 No good cause is needed.

Roughly two-thirds of states use these exemptions with little to no accountability.4 And with a stockpile of millions of exemptions currently at states’ disposal, the opportunities for abuse are widespread.5 Additionally, these exemptions carry over from year to year if unused. For example, if a state does not exempt eight percent of its ABAWD population in a given year, it can exempt 16 percent the following year.6

While this may sound like a way for bureaucrats to “benevolently” excuse ABAWDs from food stamp work requirements, in many instances there is a much more sinister motivation behind the issuance of these exemptions.

Bureaucrats are abusing no-good-cause exemptions to hide food stamp errors

Unfortunately, there is no prohibition on states issuing no-good-cause exemptions after the fact. In other words, in addition to a state applying these exemptions to prevent an ABAWD from having to work, bureaucrats can also use exemptions after that ABAWD was already supposed to have returned from work.

Why would bureaucrats want to use these exemptions retroactively? Put simply, to cover up their own mistakes. Making a mistake and failing to assign an ABAWD to work would typically increase a state’s food stamp error rate. States that have an elevated error rate for two consecutive years are subject to monetary penalties by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.7 Therefore, in theory, states have an incentive to minimize their errors by avoiding them in the first place.

Retroactively issuing no-good-cause exemptions provides a workaround for doing a good job the first time. They do not just minimize errors—they cover them up entirely. A state can retroactively excuse an ABAWD from having to return to work if that state forgot to remove them from the food stamp program for non-compliance with a work requirement. As a result, the state avoids an error.

States have brazenly admitted to engaging in this type of conduct to shield their mistakes from the federal government in order to cover up their errors. For example, California openly refers to this practice as “overissuance/error protection,” noting that “percentage exemptions may be granted to individuals who were inadvertently issued CalFresh benefits after exhausting their three countable months and who did not satisfy the work requirement or qualify for an exemption in the month that the CalFresh benefits were issued.”8

It is unsurprising that certain states are engaging in this type of conduct as there is a long history of states artificially lowering their error rates by hiding mistakes and manipulating the data.9 Even the leftist Urban Institute notes that “regional respondents reported that a common use of discretionary exemptions is to cover erroneously awarded benefits paid to ABAWDs who have exceeded their countable months.”10

This practice is widespread as states across the country are using no-good-cause exemptions to artificially depress their error rates by retroactively covering up mistakes.

In some states, up to 100 percent of no-good-cause exemptions are issued retroactively

The Foundation for Government Accountability submitted public records requests to nearly two dozen states that are known to have used no-good-cause exemptions. While many states did not provide records, the handful that did turn over responsive materials present a troubling picture.

Across just these five states over a five-year period from 2016 to 2020, roughly 100,000 no-good-cause exemptions were issued retroactively.11 In these states—and undoubtably in others as well—bureaucrats are covering up their own mistakes to hide the true extent of their errors.12

This places downward pressure on food stamp error rates, which cannot be trusted to accurately reflect true errors in the program since states can and do manipulate the data after the fact with these exemptions.

The Bottom Line: Congress must rein in no-good-cause exemptions.

In 2023, as part of the debt ceiling deal, Congress reduced the percentage of no-good-cause-exemptions that can be applied by a state to its ABAWD population in a given year from 12 percent to eight percent.13 While this is a good start, much more can be done.

Congress should ban the use of these troublesome exemptions altogether. At the very least, Congress should prohibit the retroactive application of these exemptions to minimize their abuse.

In the absence of congressional action, states should own up to their mistakes in failing to assign ABAWDs to work. These mistakes should be reflected in their food stamp error rate, not covered up after the fact. States should endeavor to do better rather than concealing their blunders.

For the sake of accountability, policymakers must get no-good-cause exemptions under control and restore integrity to the food stamp program.

title: The Latest on Medicaid Expansion and North Carolina
content:
Twelve states continue to stand strong against the pressure to expand Medicaid to able-bodied populations at the expense of the truly needy. North Carolina is one such state. With the pressure from Washington, D.C. mounting, Republicans in the North Carolina Senate have been entertaining expansion as part of a budget deal with the governor in hopes of getting out ahead of any federal mandates. It’s a very bad deal.

The Tar Heel State would be wise to dig in their heels and continue to put up a fight against expansion. The lessons learned from the 38 other states that have expanded are proof enough that it will only serve to hurt low-income North Carolinians by forcing people off private plans, crowding out essential services in the budget, and making Medicaid waiting lists even longer.

North Carolina Republicans Go Wobbly on Medicaid Expansion—From the Wall Street Journal:

“Medicaid is designed for low-income families, but Medicaid expansion brings able-bodied working-age adults into the program. Our research shows that nearly 40% of those who would be covered in North Carolina already have signed up for or have access to free federally funded private health insurance through premium tax credits—coverage they would lose if expansion passed.”

North Carolina Should Look Before It Leaps on Medicaid Expansion—From Real Clear Politics:

“As far back as 2014, Arkansas Senator Bryan King (R) warned other states not to expand after watching his state’s ‘unmitigated disaster.’ That’s what North Carolina will find when it looks at the track record of ObamaCare’s Medicaid expansion in other states. Its history is one of big but empty promises.”

Because Medicaid only pays providers a measly 60 percent of private insurance rates, only 71 percent of providers nationwide currently accept it. This frequently makes it difficult for enrollees to access care. Adding yet more people to the program promises to make this bad problem worse.”

FGA Stands Against Medicaid Expansion in North Carolina

“Medicaid expansion is welfare expansion for able-bodied adults who should be working. It will crush the state budget, take from the truly needy, and force people who already have private health insurance onto the welfare rolls.” said Sam Adolphsen, Policy Director at FGA. “A term-limited governor like Roy Cooper may not have to deal with the long-term budgetary consequences, but his constituents would pay the price – state-level cost of roughly $6 billion over 10 years. What a disaster this would be for state taxpayers, the truly needy, and North Carolina employers desperate for workers.”

Medicaid Expansion: A Boulevard of Broken Dreams for North Carolina

“Shifting patients off private health care plans and into Medicaid is a problem for providers, not a solution. In expansion states, costs are shifted to other patients and hospitals continue to struggle. In fact, non-expansion states have actually seen faster hospital job growth than expansion states.”

States Hold the Key to Unlocking Federal Medicaid Handcuffs—From Townhall:

“Being handcuffed to Leftist principles that suggest anyone should be allowed to enroll in Medicaid—even if they don’t meet the eligibility standards—is putting undue pressure on states’ welfare systems at a time when we need all available hands on deck for a strong economic recovery.”

title: Make America Healthy Again: Most States Commit to Banning Taxpayer-Funded Junk Food
content:
Overview

America’s health crisis has reached a tipping point, with chronic disease rising due to poor diet and lifestyle factors. For decades, the food stamp program has only exacerbated this problem, allowing taxpayer dollars to subsidize unhealthy food choices.

In just one year, the Trump administration has gained broad support to reverse this trend, with more than 30 states committing to healthier options for food stamps. Restricting junk food from food stamp purchases reflects a renewed focus on nutrition and health, and ensures taxpayers are no longer compelled to underwrite preventable illness and their associated medical costs.

The food stamp program has been failing to provide a more nutritious diet for enrollees

Enrollment and spending on food stamps has surged over the past 25 years, with enrollment ballooning to roughly 42 million people.1 The food stamp program exists to “safeguard the health and well-being of the nation’s population by raising levels of nutrition among low-income households.”2 Yet food stamp enrollees’ diets are worse than those not on food stamps, even among those with the same income levels.3 Children on food stamps have substandard diets and are more likely to have elevated disease risk than nonparticipants with similar incomes.4

The food stamp program is failing in its mission to provide a more nutritious diet for enrollees. In fact, soda has been the number one commodity purchased with food stamps.5 Children on food stamps consume 43 percent more sugar-sweetened beverages than nonparticipants of similar income levels.6 Sweetened beverages and candy alone account for 11 percent of all food stamp spending.7 Taxpayers are picking up the tab for a diet that is fueling disease. Taxpayers are also on the hook for the expensive treatment of this health crisis given the significant overlap in welfare programs. Seventy-two percent of food stamp enrollees are also covered by government health insurance, mostly through Medicaid.8

The food stamp program is overdue for reform to better align it with its intended purpose. Thankfully, states are committed to prohibiting the purchase of foods such as candy and sugar-sweetened beverages with food stamps.

The Trump administration is driving a national health revival and delivering historic reform to the food stamp program

More than half of states have taken action to restrict the worst foods from their food stamp programs

The Trump administration has approved waivers from 18 states to restrict food stamp purchases of soda, candy, and other detrimental foods.21 The specific restrictions differ from state to state. For example, Colorado restricts only soft drinks.22 Many other states restrict soda and candy.23 Some states also restrict energy drinks.24 The waivers go into effect throughout 2026, and USDA issued guidance for retailers to ensure a smooth transition.25 Retailers have a 90-day grace period to help identify potential issues before being subject to investigation.26 Moreover, retailers are given multiple opportunities to address evidence of non-compliance before they risk losing their authorized status.27

Some states that have not formally submitted waivers have still taken action to pursue such waivers. Several states continue to take legislative action toward food stamp waivers.28-29 Moreover, as a part of the One, Big, Beautiful Bill, all 50 states have received awards from a $50 billion initiative under the Rural Health Transformation Program.30-31 While half of the funding is distributed equally among states, the other half is granted based on a variety of factors, including a state’s commitments to MAHA-related policies.32

In their applications for rural health transformation dollars, more than 12 states are pursuing food restriction waivers.33-34 Notably, failure to implement the policy allows the federal government to withhold, reduce, or recover payments awarded based on the state’s policy commitment.35 This brings the total number of states that have implemented or are pursuing food stamp waivers to more than 30.36-37

The Bottom Line:

In just one year, the Trump administration has garnered support and prompted bold action from states to make America healthy again.

The Trump administration is restoring the purpose of the food stamp program. The chronic disease epidemic has reached critical levels, and the Make America Healthy Again movement is receiving widespread support. At the state level, policymakers are committed to stopping taxpayer-funded junk food. States are stepping up, restoring real nutrition to food stamps through

commonsense reforms.

title: Congress Should Stop Runaway Spending by Enacting Discretionary Spending Caps in Reconciliation
content:
Background

The national debt has surged to more than $38.42 trillion.1 In 1984, it was considered a crisis when the national debt reached 39 percent of gross domestic product (GDP).2 Today, the debt is a shocking 125 percent of GDP.3 By 2055, the debt is projected to reach nearly $138 trillion.4 Interest payments on the debt are already $970 billion annually, costing nearly 20 percent of federal revenue.5 By 2055, interest payments on the national debt alone are projected to cost nearly $4.8 trillion.6

Allowing the national debt to grow unchecked will be devastating for future economic growth. Increasing federal debt reduces the availability of funds for private investment, driving up interest rates and slowing economic growth.7 The current debt trajectory will lead to more than one million fewer jobs over the next decade.8 Rising debt also erodes the value of Treasury securities, potentially causing financial institutions to fail, which would trigger global economic turmoil.9

The debt crisis is driven by skyrocketing federal spending.10 During the Biden administration, federal spending grew substantially. Total federal spending soared from $4.4 trillion in 2019 to $6.8 trillion in 2024, a 40 percent increase.11 In 2024, federal spending exceeded revenues by nearly $2 trillion.12

Reforming categories of spending, such as health care, that drive the bulk of mandatory spending will be necessary to solve the debt crisis.13 However, discretionary spending is also on an unsustainable growth trajectory, and enacting spending caps can help stop excessive federal spending and reduce the deficit.

Capping discretionary spending would slow the growth of federal spending and reduce the deficit

Discretionary spending is the category of spending that Congress appropriates on an annual basis, and includes defense spending, operations budgets for federal agencies, and programs including food stamps and small business loans.14 Medicare, Social Security, and some other programs that are not subject to annual spending bills are categorized as mandatory spending.15 Changing mandatory spending requires changes to eligibility or benefits for major programs like Social Security.16 In contrast, Congress can slow down discretionary spending immediately without having to agree on significant and politically challenging reforms.

Discretionary spending has ballooned in the last decade. In 2014, annual appropriations totaled $1.1 trillion.17 In 2024, discretionary spending reached $1.8 trillion, a 63 percent increase in 10 years.18

In 2023, Congress passed the Fiscal Responsibility Act, which capped discretionary spending for fiscal years 2024 and 2025.19 This legislation reduced non-defense discretionary spending by more than $110 billion compared to CBO’s baseline projections.20 This legislation also established spending targets for fiscal year 2026 through 2029, allowing for just one percent annual growth in discretionary spending levels.21

Overall, the Fiscal Responsibility Act reduced projections of the debt by $1.5 trillion.22 Congress should build on the successful deficit reduction in the Fiscal Responsibility Act and pass discretionary spending caps enforced through sequestration to reduce the national debt and slow down runaway federal spending.

Spending caps are fair game in budget reconciliation

Each year, budget reconciliation legislation can be considered to bring spending levels and revenues in line with a budget resolution.23 The reconciliation legislation only requires a simple majority to pass the Senate, rather than 60 votes.24 Since the budget reconciliation process is an opportunity to pass legislation that does not have the support to overcome a filibuster, the Byrd rule serves as a six-part test to ensure that a legislative provision is budgetary in nature and eligible for inclusion in reconciliation legislation.25

The Byrd rule renders a provision extraneous, and therefore ineligible to be included in reconciliation if it fails to produce changes to outlays or revenue, produces changes to outlays or revenue beyond the budget instructions, is outside the committee of jurisdiction for the respective title, produces changes in outlays or revenues that are incidental to the non-budgetary facets of the provision, increases the deficit in years beyond the budget period outlined by the bill, or amends the old age, survivors, and disability insurance programs under the Social Security Act.26

The Byrd rule does not make a distinction between mandatory spending and discretionary spending. Changes to discretionary appropriations produce changes in outlays and therefore meet the Byrd rule test.

When determining if a provision can be included in reconciliation, members of the majority and minority parties make arguments before the Senate Parliamentarian, who issues an advisory opinion.27 The ultimate decision on whether a provision can be included is made by the President of the Senate—the Vice President—or whoever is presiding over the Senate at the time in his place.28

Senate rules, including the Byrd rule, are guided substantially by precedent.29 The precedent set by previous Byrd rule decisions is an important part of the arguments made for and against the inclusion of provisions and should guide the opinion of the parliamentarian.30 Discretionary spending caps are eligible for inclusion in reconciliation based on precedent alone.

Two reconciliation bills in the 1990s included discretionary spending caps, enforced through sequestration. First, the Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1990 included a provision that established spending caps through fiscal year 1995.31 These spending caps were enforced through automatic sequestration if the spending targets were exceeded by appropriations legislation.32 In 1993, budget reconciliation was used to extend the caps through 1998.33

Even setting aside precedent, spending caps clearly meet the requirements of the Byrd rule. Discretionary spending caps reduce outlays and the deficit, a primary goal of the Byrd rule. Slowing the growth of discretionary spending is purely budgetary and has no relationship to unrelated policy priorities. Setting discretionary spending caps does not impact the programs in the Social Security Act that are unallowable under the Byrd rule, and the provision can be crafted to meet the other requirements related to the committees of jurisdiction and the budget window.

The Bottom Line:

Congress should use budget reconciliation to enact discretionary spending caps, which would slow down runaway federal spending and reduce the national debt.

The reconciliation process is reserved for budgetary matters that impact outlays and revenues, and the only goal of setting discretionary spending caps is to reduce outlays and the deficit. Discretionary spending is increasingly rising to unsustainable levels. If Congress does not act, runaway spending will continue to explode the national debt, and future generations will pay the price.

The reconciliation process was successfully used in the past to enact and enforce discretionary spending caps, and Congress should use this tool again to ensure fiscal responsibility and deficit reduction.

title: Minnesota Fraud Scandal Proves Trump, Republicans Were Right on Welfare Reform
content:
For years, the Left has been working overtime to convince the American people that welfare fraud doesn’t exist—that it’s a myth, it’s rare, or it’s Republicans stigmatizing poor people.

They’ve done everything possible—even altering the ways improper payments are counted—to distract from the fact that welfare fraud is extremely common, a major problem, and jeopardizes the future of our nation’s welfare programs.

Minnesota’s $9 billion welfare fraud scandal makes it impossible to ignore any longer.

Instead of feeding the hungry or providing medical services, shady non-profit workers were billing the state for services they never delivered and pocketing hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayer money. This money went towards real estate, luxury goods, and funding terrorists in Somalia.

Whistleblowers sounded the alarm, only for Governor Tim Walz to silence them out of fear of being called a racist.

Ironically, while all of this was happening on his watch, the governor dared to call federal welfare reform “cruel” for cutting back on fraud and requiring part-time work for able-bodied adults.

Spare us, Mr. Governor.

Hardworking Minnesotans diligently pay their taxes while struggling to afford necessities thanks to Biden’s cost-of-living crisis, but Governor Walz let fraudsters run off with hundreds of millions of their tax dollars—money they aren’t likely to get back. It now appears that a similar situation played out in Maine.

Rep. Ilhan Omar was right—a lack of guardrails in welfare does lead to fraud. Which is why it’s so puzzling that she and the rest of the Democrats in Congress and state capitals across the country fight so hard to stop program integrity efforts. Because while the circumstances around the Minnesota fraud scandal may be unique, welfare waste in general is not. In fact, Minnesota is just a drop in the bucket.

As Michael Greibrok notes in a new report for the Foundation for Government Accountability (FGA), more than one in every five dollars spent on Medicaid is improper. Before the One, Big, Beautiful Bill, the program was on track to have more than $2 trillion in improper payments over the next decade.

Federal auditors have also determined that more than 450,000 Medicaid payments were made on behalf of deceased enrollees. This cost taxpayers $249 million.

In food stamps, an estimated $2 billion of taxpayer money is lost every year to benefits trafficking. For fiscal year 2023, $10.5 billion in food stamp payments were improper, and 42 states have error rates at or above six percent.

Lackluster eligibility verification, waiver overuse, and abusing loopholes to funnel resources to illegal immigrants are some of the many ways states have let waste, fraud, and abuse take root in their welfare programs. Every dollar wasted on someone who was ineligible for welfare—or on shady non-profits that don’t actually help anyone—is a dollar that cannot be used for truly needy Americans who rely on these programs.

President Trump and Republicans in Congress knew the truth: Welfare fraud is rampant, and states need to be encouraged—or outright pushed—to get their programs under control.

That’s why they were right to pass federal welfare reform. Thanks to their efforts, states like Minnesota and California no longer have the option to sit idly by and rely on federal taxpayers for rescue.

The One, Big, Beautiful Bill:

Cracks down on waste, fraud, and abuse by removing people who are deceased, enrolled in multiple states, or otherwise ineligible.

Requires able-bodied adults without young children to work, train, or volunteer as a condition of receiving Medicaid.

Ends federal Medicaid funding for illegal aliens.

Limits states’ ability to shift their costs onto federal taxpayers through money laundering schemes.

Minnesota’s fraud scandal is shining a light on the state of welfare in America—and Americans aren’t liking what they’re seeing. The good news is that President Trump and congressional Republicans have already paved the way for states to restore integrity to welfare and cut waste, fraud, and abuse out of government programs that are meant to serve those who rely on them.

title: 100 Days In, Governor Braun Is Making Indiana Great Again
content:
Promises made, promises kept.

Wednesday, April 23 marked 100 days in office for Governor Mike Braun, and Indiana has a lot to celebrate. From shrinking bureaucracy to restoring welfare program integrity and launching a comprehensive health agenda, Governor Braun’s Freedom and Opportunity agenda has earned its name, with the promise of so much more to come.

Governor Braun himself summed it up well earlier this year when discussing his deregulatory goals:

“Whenever you’re doing something like this, there’s always risk associated. … Most governors — and I’m going to say even most legislators — are generally risk averse. I can tell you, if you’re naturally risk averse, you’re going to be in a broad band of mediocrity.”

There is nothing mediocre about what Governor Braun has accomplished for the Hoosier State, and he has only just begun. Here’s a look at some of his biggest wins yet:

A leaner, more service-oriented state government

Governor Braun has made streamlining government and making state agencies more transparent a top priority. He signed an executive order directing state agencies to reduce their regulatory burdens by 25 percent by 2029. He is encouraging inter-agency communications to help reduce the number of hurdles people need to overcome to access state services. And he is promoting work by removing burdensome degree requirements for state jobs and directing state agencies to reduce licensing requirements wherever prudent.

Getting rid of DEI and ESG

Bye, bye, DEI! Governor Braun shifted the state’s focus on diversity, equity, and inclusion toward MEI, or merit, excellence, and innovation. DEI is divisive, expensive, and inefficient—and Governor Braun is right to refocus his state on encouraging the best and brightest, regardless of background, to pursue excellence. He doubled down on this when he prohibited the use of environmental justice in permitting, enforcement, or grant decisions.

Assessing waste, fraud, and abuse in welfare spending

Ensuring the integrity of welfare programs is critical to the government’s ability to provide services to those who truly need them. To restore program integrity in Indiana, Governor Braun directed state agencies to utilize and cross-check all available resources to verify the eligibility of benefit recipients. Similarly, Indiana’s Medicaid program was in dire straits when Governor Braun took office. With diligent work from the General Assembly and a governor-directed assessment on state Medicaid spending, Indiana is on its way to righting the ship.

Launching the Making Indiana Healthy Again initiative

Earlier this month, Governor Braun hosted Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Administrator Dr. Mehmet Oz for a Make Indiana Healthy Again event in Indianapolis. Governor Braun signed nine executive orders aimed at helping Hoosiers live longer and healthier lives, including a widely supported ban on junk food in food stamps.

Governor Braun spent his first 100 days delivering on the promises he made to Hoosiers. We can’t wait to see what he does next!

title: REINS
content:
As President Biden continues his regulatory assault on America’s economy, Congress can REIN in regulatory overreach, which would help tame inflation and runaway spending.

The Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act would prevent any president from unilaterally wrapping the economy in red tape that drives up the cost of energy and busts household budgets. In 2023, this important legislation has been introduced in the Senate (S. 184) and House (H.R. 277), but has not been voted on.

Congress is not only permitted—but also constitutionally required—to decide major questions of nationwide policy. The REINS Act would bolster that mandate by giving Congress the legislative power to approve major rules before they go into effect. The REINS Act would broaden the Congressional Review Act to require congressional approval of major rules—those with an annual price tag of $100 million or more—before federal agencies could implement them.

HIGHLIGHTS

In his first year, President Biden finalized regulations adding more than $200 billion in new regulatory costs—more than quadruple the costs added during President Obama’s first year. Cumulative regulatory costs have continued to climb since 2009, ballooning to $1.1 trillion under the Biden administration.

title: How States Can Shrink Bloated Bureaucracy and Save Taxpayer Dollars
content:
Government at all levels is plagued by bureaucratic inefficiencies and bloat, which waste taxpayer money and impose a burden on residents. While reducing the size of the federal government is important, it is crucial that state and local governments are not overlooked. Reducing tax burdens and shrinking state and local government promotes economic freedom and allows residents to thrive.1 However, government only continues to grow. Currently, there are more than 20 million state and local government employees nationwide.2 Since the start of 2023, state and local government employment has grown by more than 730,000 jobs and has surpassed the previous peak by more than 320,000 employees.3

In 2023, there were 19.5 million state and local government employees nationwide, with 5.3 million employed by a state government and 14.2 million employed by a local government.4 In total, wages alone for these employees are estimated to cost taxpayers more than $1.23 trillion.5 The cost of providing health care, retirement, and other benefits to these employees adds billions more in costs.6 The number of employees and payroll costs vary widely by state, with California spending more than $185 billion annually on wages for its 2.3 million employees and South Dakota spending slightly more than $2.6 billion on wages for its 65,000 employees.7

While private sector employment has also been on the rise in recent years, government employment has been growing at a faster pace than other types of employment since March 2023.8 Additionally, state and local government employment is virtually immune from economic factors. In 2020, private sector jobs fell from 129 million to 108 million—a drop of 16 percent—while government jobs only fell by three percent.9 During the Great Recession, government employment grew while private employment plummeted.10

The compensation of government employees is much higher than in the private sector

As of June 2024, the total employer cost—which includes wages and benefits—for the average private sector employee was $43.78 per hour.11 Total employer costs for the average government employee was $61.27 per hour.12 Total compensation is 40 percent higher for public sector employees compared to private sector employees, and benefits are 80 percent higher.13 Additionally, over the last 12 months, the compensation of government employees has increased at a faster rate than other occupations.14

Going beyond averages to account for differences in education and job type, government employees earn more than private sector employees in the same field for most types of jobs.15 The difference is especially stark in fields like services and sales and office occupations.16 For example, government employees in the service sector earn more than double what their private sector counterparts earn, and their benefits are four times higher.17

Government is also slow to react to changing needs, meaning that some positions remain even when they are no longer needed. In June 2024, the involuntary separation rate for private employees was 3.6 percent compared to 1.2 percent for government employees.18 This means that private sector employees are three times more likely to be terminated or laid off compared to government employees.19 Labor unions and archaic policies prevent even poor performers and those with misconduct from being terminated.20

Excessive employee benefits are imperiling state and local budgets

Salaries and benefits for government employees consume a large portion of state spending.21 For example, an analysis of North Carolina’s 2022 budget shows that 66 percent of state income tax revenue was spent on salaries and benefits for state employees.22

In addition to salaries, government pension and retiree health care benefits are extremely generous compared to private sector benefits.23 A whopping 86 percent of state and local employees have access to a defined benefit pension compared to just 15 percent of private sector employees.24 The cost to employers for retirement benefits for government employees is more than four times the cost for private sector employees.25

These benefits are extremely expensive and are bankrupting local governments, forcing cuts to services for taxpayers.26 Chicago faces a $37.1 billion debt to city employee pension funds, and the state of Illinois has an unfunded pension liability equal to 212.3 percent of state revenue.27-28 In 2021, total unfunded pension liabilities for all states reached $836 billion—49 percent of states’ revenue.29

From 2000 to 2018, the share of all states’ K-12 education budgets that went to employee pension funds nearly doubled, increasing from 7.5 percent to 14.4 percent.30 In total, salaries and benefits are nearly 80 percent of education spending, driving the 13 percent rise in cost per student since 2010.31

State and local governments are feeling dual pressure: ever-growing pension and benefit liabilities and the demands of public-sector unions for even more generous wages and benefits. Nearly 40 percent of state and local government employees are members of a union, compared to just six percent of private sector employees.32 In contract negotiations, unions push for increases to salaries and benefits that taxpayers simply cannot afford.33

Overregulation and burdensome government intervention are associated with high numbers of government employees

It is not just state and local budgets that are impacted by an inefficient, sprawling government. States with more government employees also have more regulations, and a higher regulatory burden on businesses and residents.

When new regulations are added to the books, government employment goes up. For example, the state of Minnesota recently imposed new regulations related to legalizing marijuana, which are projected to require more than 200 new government positions to implement.34 Other new welfare programs created by the most recent spending legislation are expected to lead to more than 1,000 new government employees in the state.35

States should cut down on waste and inefficiency by reducing the size of the bureaucracy

State governments can save taxpayer dollars and reduce bureaucratic inefficiency by reducing the size of government. Government agencies are often slow to respond to change, and open positions can remain unfilled for months or even years yet remain as a line-item in an agency budget.36 At best, leaving a government position unfilled for months suggests its functions are not necessary, and that the post does not need to be filled in the future. However, some state and local government agencies intentionally do not recruit for open positions, leaving them unfilled so they can use the funds allocated for those salaries for other purposes.37

To reduce unnecessary bureaucracy and save taxpayer dollars, states should eliminate government positions that have been open for months. For example, in Nebraska, the executive budget division must review and reauthorize any positions that have been open for more than 90 days.38 And upon request, the executive state personnel division may determine whether these vacant positions are properly classified. As such, the governor may direct the divisions to review and eliminate these positions to permanently reduce the size of the bureaucracy.39 Recently, this policy led to the elimination of nearly 500 positions, saving $26 million in the budget.40

States should also lift restrictions that slow down government hiring and firing to make departments more efficient and agile. Even though most states are “at will,” there remain numerous barriers to dismissal, demotion, suspension, or other discipline of government employees despite poor performance or misconduct. Mississippi law allows for agencies to request temporary exemptions from civil service laws that make it too difficult to fire bad employees or make necessary changes to the agency.41 After reviewing the agency’s request and plan for action during the exemption period, the legislature may temporarily codify an exemption from civil service laws in statute. During exemption periods where restrictions were lifted on an agency, terminations in most departments substantially increased, and human resources directors reported department operations improved.42

The Bottom Line: States should reduce the size of bloated and inefficient bureaucracy to save taxpayer dollars and limit burdensome government intervention.

The role of state and local government is to provide public services to taxpayers. However, far too often bureaucracy grows and makes government less efficient and more burdensome to residents and businesses. It is important for state governments to save taxpayer dollars and cut back where there are inefficient departments or positions that are no longer needed.

Government employees’ salaries and benefits cost trillions, and to be good stewards of taxpayer dollars, states should reduce the size of government.

title: FGA Amicus Curiae Brief in Support of Missouri Court’s Ruling Striking Down the Medicaid Expansion Amendment as Unconstitutional
content:
On July 7, 2021, the Foundation for Government Accountability (FGA) filed an amicus curiae brief with the Supreme Court of Missouri in support of the lower court’s ruling that the Medicaid Expansion Amendment violates Missouri’s Constitution.

In the brief, FGA explains that the ballot initiative that narrowly passed last fall violates Article III Section 51 of the Missouri Constitution as it failed to provide a source of funding to pay for its massive cost. FGA also argues that the large, unanticipated costs associated with Medicaid expansion demand a valid source of funding upfront to avoid decimating the State’s budget.

FGA ends the brief by warning the Court that allowing this unconstitutional amendment to survive would transform Missouri’s initiative process into a mechanism for well-funded special interest groups to use to avoid the legislative process crippling the State’s budget while undermining the separation of powers enshrined in the Missouri Constitution.

title: Myth vs. Fact: Mandatory Employment and Training Under the General Work Requirement in Food Stamps
content:
MYTH #1:

“Food stamp work requirements are suspended due to the COVID-19 pandemic.”

FACT:

There are two separate work requirements in the food stamp program and Congress only suspended one. One work requirement is for all work registrants, and another is specifically for certain able-bodied adults without dependents (ABAWDs). The first and broader requirement for all work registrants is called the “general work requirement.”

The second and more narrow work requirement for ABAWDs is called the “ABAWD work requirement.” Congress suspended the ABAWD work requirement entirely when it passed the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) in March 2020.1 That suspension will remain in effect until the president allows the public health emergency declaration to expire.2

But Congress did not suspend the general work requirement for any work registrants or prohibit mandatory E&T.

MYTH #2:

“Mandatory Employment and Training (E&T) under the general work requirement is unnecessary because there is already a work requirement in food stamps.”

FACT:

The ABAWD work requirement, as explained above, is one of two work requirements in food stamps but is far better known than the general work requirement. The two requirements operate differently and apply to different but overlapping populations.

The general work requirement applies to all work registrants. ABAWDs are a subgroup within the work registrant population who are between the ages of 18 and 49 and who have no dependent children.3 ABAWDs can comply with the ABAWD work requirement by working, training, or volunteering for at least 20 hours per week, including by participating in a state’s E&T program.4

Work registrants, on the other hand, include ABAWDs but also able- bodied parents of school-aged children and able-bodied, childless adults between 50 and 59 years old.5

But without mandatory E&T in the general work requirement, these additional groups of able-bodied adults on food stamps are not subject to any work requirement.

MYTH #3:

“We already have mandatory E&T under the general work requirement.”

FACT:

Nine states—Florida, Idaho, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Dakota, Ohio, Texas, and Utah—have instituted some form of mandatory E&T.9 Arkansas will soon join them. The state is in the process of implementing mandatory E&T, as passed by the state legislature in 2019.10

MYTH #4:

“No other states use mandatory E&T.”

FACT:

States are not required to provide an E&T slot for every work registrant to begin implementing mandatory E&T.

States that use mandatory E&T often grant many exemptions to work registrants. For example, even before the COVID-19 pandemic, Utah exempted 68 percent of its work registrants from participation and Ohio exempted 58 percent.9-10

More to the point, even among mandatory E&T participants assigned to slots, participation will be lower than 100 percent. Some may participate. Many others will fail to comply and be removed from food stamps. And even more will simply get a job and leave the program.

MYTH #5:

“My state doesn’t have enough money to provide an E&T slot for every work registrant in the state.”

FACT:

States are not required to provide an E&T slot for every work registrant to begin implementing mandatory E&T.

States that use mandatory E&T often grant many exemptions to work registrants. For example, even before the COVID-19 pandemic, Utah exempted 68 percent of its work registrants from participation and Ohio exempted 58 percent.11-12

More to the point, even among mandatory E&T participants assigned to slots, participation will be lower than 100 percent. Some may participate. Many others will fail to comply and be removed from food stamps. And even more will simply get a job and leave the program.

MYTH #6:

“The federal Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) has said states must provide a slot for everyone in order to implement mandatory E&T.”

FACT:

States are not required to provide an E&T slot for every work registrant to begin implementing mandatory E&T. Any statement to that effect directly contradicts federal law and previous, written agency guidance.

States are required to assist, with help from federal funding streams, those who do participate in the E&T program, including case management and monthly supervision.13

But states are not required to prospectively build a massive infrastructure for every work registrant based on false assumptions of complete participation. Federal regulations specifically allow E&T programs to operate without the capacity to serve all enrollees.14

In fact, FNS has specifically clarified that, for example, “if a State agency requires 175 participants to participate in E&T, but the State agency has only provided 100 slots with appropriate services for those individuals, then the State agency must provide good cause to the 75 individuals who do not have access to a slot with appropriate services.”15

MYTH #7:

“The state doesn’t have enough money to implement mandatory E&T.”

FACT:

Every state already operates an E&T program for food stamp enrollees and additional federal funding for mandatory E&T is available.16

The federal government provides 100 percent reimbursement for E&T administration costs up to each state’s biennial grant.17 These funds can cover the “planning, implementation, and operation” of an E&T program.18 This does not include initial applicant screening but it does include initial E&T assessments.19 States which use their E&T grant funding can receive additional federal funds upon request in the interim year from states which did not use their funds.20

Even if a state exceeds its annual grant, states continue to receive 50 percent federal reimbursement for additional E&T administrative costs.21 They also receive 50 percent federal reimbursement for participant reimbursements for expenditures like childcare and transportation.22

Additionally, on an ongoing basis, tens of millions of federal dollars in “ABAWD pledge funding” are available to states if they offer all ABAWDs in their third month of enrollment an E&T slot.23-24

Finally, funds appropriated in the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (ARPA) can be used for many E&T administrative expenses allowable under, including agency and contractual costs.25

MYTH #8:

“Even with more federal funds, state costs are too high to implement mandatory E&T.”

FACT:

The additional financial burden of mandatory E&T is often wildly overstated for a number of reasons.

First, states have flexibility in what the “slots” are to which work registrants are assigned. They need not be well-funded programs in community colleges or career centers. Slots can constitute any simple check-in program that would allow an enrollee to meet the requirement, including work experience and volunteering.

Second, other costs associated with mandatory E&T such as transportation and childcare reimbursements, tend to be much lower than expected. Estimates often assume that all work registrants will participate and that, among these participants, all will need transportation assistance. Both are deeply flawed assumptions. For example, Texas, a big state with a big E&T program, only spends $1.8 million for transportation costs.26

Similarly, a small minority of the work registrants are responsible for the care of small children not old enough to be in school. Those in that minority will receive subsidized funding for childcare through TANF, the Child Care Development Block grant, or other state and federal childcare programs. Again, Texas only budgets $4,000 for childcare reimbursement statewide.27

MYTH #9:

“Mandatory E&T is far too burdensome to administer.”

FACT:

States have enormous flexibilities in administering E&T programs. Specifically, states have a number of options for how they can track participants, check in on job searches, how often agencies provide participants services, and the extent to which third-party “E&T partners” assume responsibilities, including case management.28-29

Fear of administrative burden often comes from an over-emphasis on the “training” portion of “employment and training.” But employment services, especially in partnership with private employers and “work partnerships,” are much less burdensome for the state and can effectively move able-bodied adults into work settings which often become jobs.30

Specifically, “work experience” is an E&T component under federal law and includes actual work activity performed in exchange for food stamp benefits.31 For example, in Texas’s mandatory E&T program, the state assigns participants to work activities, rather than automatically assigning them

to community college or longer-term training programs, although those programs are still available for some.

MYTH #10:

“The federal Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) has said states must provide a slot for everyone in order to implement mandatory E&T.”

FACT:

States with limited funding can choose to prioritize ABAWDs for mandatory E&T. This is especially important when the federal government waives the ABAWD work requirement, such as during the ongoing public health emergency related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Even before the pandemic, some states only used mandatory E&T for ABAWDs rather than all work registrants, including Florida, Mississippi, and Ohio.32

MYTH #11:

“Work requirements don’t work, especially for work registrants not already subject to the ABAWD work requirement like parents and adults 50-59.”

FACT:

Work requirements in food stamps rank among the most effective tools in lifting individuals out of dependency into self-sufficiency.33 Studies across multiple states have demonstrated how able-bodied adults leaving food stamps after work requirements are implemented find work in thousands of diverse industries and see their incomes more than triple.34

Work registrants who are not ABAWDs but still able-bodied, particularly parents, are among the individuals who can benefit the most from higher incomes and reconnecting with their communities.35

MYTH #12:

“If a state exempts ABAWDs from mandatory E&T because they don’t have enough slots, it will exempt ABAWDs from the ABAWD work requirement and result in fewer people working.”

FACT:

If an ABAWD receives a good cause exemption from mandatory E&T, it usually means they’re also exempt from the ABAWD work requirement.36 But that’s not always true. FNS has clarified that if an ABAWD only receives a good cause exemption from mandatory E&T because the program did not have an open slot, that exemption does not carry over to the individual’s ABAWD work requirement because E&T participation is only one of many ways in which an individual can comply with the ABAWD work requirement.37

MYTH #13:

“Mandatory E&T under the general work requirement doesn’t provide flexibility for non-compliance.”

FACT:

States have discretion in setting their own standards for non-compliance sanctions. States have discretion to disqualify individuals for one to three months after the first failure to comply, three to six months after the second failure to comply, and six months or even permanently for the third failure.38

Furthermore, even among able-bodied enrollees, many will be exempt from mandatory E&T under the general work requirement because they take care of a child under six years old or an incapacitated person, participate in an alcohol or drug treatment program, are in school, or already work at least 30 hours per week or earn equivalent wages.39

title: FGA Applauds Introduction of the Make Elections Great Again Act
content:
Chairman Steil’s bill would establish baseline election integrity requirements and protect federal elections across the United States.

NAPLES, FL – The Foundation for Government Accountability (FGA) today praised Rep. Bryan Steil (R-WI), Chair of the House Administration Committee, for introducing the Make Elections Great Again (MEGA) Act (H.R. 7300). This bill would require baseline election integrity protections across the states to keep federal elections secure and prevent bad actors from abusing state election laws to influence results.

The MEGA Act’s election integrity protections include:

• Requiring stronger, routine voter list maintenance in states

• Requiring photo identification to vote

• Requiring states to verify the citizenship status of individuals when registering to vote

• Requiring mail-in ballots to be received no later than the close of polls on Election Day

• Banning ballot harvesting, universal vote by mail, and ranked-choice voting

“Chairman Steil’s bill comes at an important time, as our representative electoral system faces an onslaught of activists and legislators trying to weaken election integrity, from ranked-choice voting schemes to preventing immigration enforcementnear polling places,” said Madeline Malisa, Policy Director for the Foundation for Government Accountability. “Election integrity protections are not only common sense—they’re extremely popular, with an overwhelming majority of voters supporting voter ID and allowing only citizens to vote.”

“Chairman Steil’s bill builds on the hard work that many states have done to strengthen election integrity and protect the vote and reinforces that bad actors will not be allowed to game the system. Free and fair elections are foundational to the greatness of this country, and all efforts must be made to protect them,” added FGA’s Madeline Malisa.

Polling shows broad, bipartisan popularity of election integrity reforms. title: President Trump’s Crackdown on Institutional Investors Will Unlock Homeownership
content:
Overview

Homeownership has always been an essential element of the American Dream. Owning a home is a form of freedom from the instability of renting, and a way for average families to build wealth that can be passed down to their children. Unfortunately, homeownership is increasingly out of reach for many American families.

The cost of homeownership surged during the Biden administration. In 2020, the median home price was $338,600.1 But by the end of 2024, the median home price had risen to $419,300—a 24 percent increase in just four years.2

The Biden administration’s inflationary policies caused interest rates to soar from 2.7 percent in January 2021 to seven percent in January 2025, reaching a high of nearly eight percent in October 2024.3 As a result, the median monthly mortgage payment doubled from 2020 to 2024.4

The median home price is currently $410,800, and the median monthly mortgage payment, assuming a 20 percent down payment with a 30-year mortgage is $2,198.5-6 Property taxes and insurance drive the monthly cost of homeownership even higher.7 Nearly 75 percent of households cannot afford the mortgage on a median-priced home.8

Those fortunate enough to have bought their home prior to the surge in cost are now less likely to move, which constricts supply.9 Currently, individuals are remaining in their homes without selling for an average of 12 years, double the time that the average homeowner stayed in the early 2000s.10 It is estimated that the extreme spike in interest rates from 2022 to 2024 prevented 1.72 million home sales over the course of two years.11 If interest rates had remained low, home sales would have been doubled.12

Even though interest rates have dipped since President Trump has taken office, persistent low supply continues to be a problem. Americans’ demand outpaces supply by 4.7 million homes.13

One factor exacerbating low supply and high prices is large institutional investors buying single-family homes and crowding out American families in cities across the country.

Institutional investors are crowding out working families

In 2011, no company owned more than 1,000 single-family homes.14 But by 2022, more than 450,000 single-family homes were owned by institutional investors—companies owning 1,000 or more properties.15 The five largest institutional investors owned more than 300,000 single-family homes.16Real estate investors purchased 33 percent of single-family homes sold in the second quarter of 2025.17

A review of 500 counties across the country found that 8.9 percent of residential properties were owned by corporate investors.18 Institutional investors intentionally target fast-growing metropolitan areas and focus their efforts on specific communities in order to manage properties more efficiently.19 In fast-growing communities concentrated in the south, these investors own a shocking percentage of homes.20

In Atlanta, where 25 percent of the single-family rental market is owned by institutional investors, the presence of concentrated corporate ownership is responsible for 25 percent of the decline in homeownership among Atlanta-metro neighborhoods.21

Buying a home in a competitive real estate market is already a difficult task for families that may be able to afford the mortgage, but do not have a large reserve of cash for a down payment. Competing against corporations that can make all-cash offers is an uphill battle that most families will lose.

Institutional investors are contributing to homes being unaffordable

Not only are institutional investors buying homes that could have otherwise been purchased by a family, but their presence in a real estate market drives up home prices. When an institutional investor buys a foreclosed property, nearby home prices increase 1.4 percent in total value more than properties that are further away.22 The effect is even more significant when looking at houses that are similar to ones purchased by institutional investors and the least expensive neighborhoods in a geographic area.23

In the same markets that are saturated by institutional investor-owned homes, prices are rising, and homeownership is increasingly unaffordable. For example, in Franklin County, Ohio, 20 percent of residential properties are owned by corporations.24 In this county, home prices have increased by nearly 50 percent since 2020.25 In Clarke County, Georgia, 19 percent of properties are owned by corporations, and prices have increased nearly 60 percent.26-27

President Trump has issued an executive order to crack down on institutional investors

President Trump has recognized institutional investors as one of the factors contributing to the rising cost of homeownership and in January 2026, President Trump issued an executive order to crack down on these corporations taking over neighborhoods.28

This executive order directs federal agencies to issue guidance preventing government entities from facilitating the purchase of a single-family home by an institutional investor if that home could otherwise be purchased by an owner-occupant.29 It also directs agencies to develop guidance that would promote sales to individuals and families through first-look policies, disclosure requirements, and anti-circumvention provisions.30 Another provision asks the Federal Trade Commission to review purchases by institutional investors for anti-competitive impacts on housing markets.31

Lastly, the executive order calls on Congress to codify the policies outlined in the order.32

The Bottom Line: Homeownership is a critical part of achieving the American Dream. Congress should follow President Trump’s lead and stop large institutional investors from crowding out American families.

Owning a home is the hallmark of the American Dream for good reason. Homeownership builds wealth and equity that can be passed down to future generations, and creates stable, connected neighborhoods. Unfortunately, due to the record-high inflation and interest rate spikes during the Biden administration, homeownership is increasingly impossible for many families. Institutional investors able to make more competitive, all-cash offers on homes, crowd out average families.

The data shows that when corporate ownership of homes increases in a given community, homeownership rates fall.33 Stopping the largest institutions from buying single-family homes will stop the constriction of supply and slow the trend of skyrocketing prices, opening the door to homeownership for more Americans.

To level the playing field and give families a chance at homeownership, President Trump has taken action to end the growing trend of institutional investors purchasing thousands of homes. This is an important step toward making homeownership more accessible for more families, and Congress should act to codify this policy.

content: Congress and the Trump Administration Are Strengthening Work Requirements and Protecting the Truly Needy on Food Stamps January 14, 2026 BY Alli Fick , Paige Terryberry SHARE DOWNLOAD PAPER [PDF] Issues How the ObamaCare Dependency Crisis Could Get Even Worse — and How to Stop It January 16, 2018 Unmasking the Unemployment Crisis: The new pandemic plaguing America June 10, 2021 How the New Era of Expanded Welfare Programs is Keeping Americans from Working November 11, 2021 STOP RIGHT THERE! Email Key Findings Most able-bodied adults on food stamps do not work at all. The One, Big, Beautiful Bill brought greater accountability to food stamps by strengthening work requirements and closing loopholes. USDA should now update FNS regulations to align with the One, Big, Beautiful Bill and help move people from welfare to work. The Bottom Line: USDA should strengthen food stamp work requirements by eliminating unlawful exemptions and restoring the secretary’s discretion to reject waiver requests. Background In July 2025, President Trump signed the One, Big, Beautiful Bill into law. 1 The law fundamentally transformed the food stamp program, protecting the truly needy by curbing waste, fraud, and abuse, and ensuring accountability. The law also strengthened the program’s work requirements. Notably, work requirements for able-bodied adults without dependents were expanded to include able-bodied adults up to age 64 and parents of children ages 14 and older. 2 Work requirements have a proven track record of success in moving able-bodied adults out of dependency and into self-sufficiency. 3-8 The One, Big, Beautiful Bill also cracked down on bureaucratic loopholes used by states to waive work requirements for millions of able-bodied adults on food stamps. 9 The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) should now amend Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) regulations to ensure that they are not broader than what is in statute and intended by Congress. By strengthening work requirements, USDA can ensure food stamps benefit the truly needy. Most able-bodied adults on food stamps do not work at all The food stamp program requires some able-bodied adults to work, train, or volunteer as a condition of eligibility. 10 Even with this connection to work, able-bodied adults have been flooding the food stamp rolls. 11 Since 2000, the number of able-bodied adults on food stamps has nearly tripled. 12 For decades, states have used loopholes and gimmicks to game the system and waive work requirements for as many able-bodied adults as possible. 13 Worse, the Obama and Biden administrations actively pressured states to waive work requirements, trapping them in a cycle of dependency. 14 The result is an influx of able-bodied adults on food stamps, at the expense of the truly needy. Most able-bodied adults on food stamps do not work at all, as most are exempt from work requirements. 15 In 2023, more than 80 percent of able-bodied adults without dependents were exempt from work requirements. 16 Thanks to loopholes, states have waived work requirements for millions of adults, even in areas with low unemployment. 17 Waiver abuse is rampant. 18 And federal regulations are broader than what is in statute, creating confusion and maximizing program enrollment beyond what was intended by Congress. USDA should eliminate unlawful exemptions to work requirements For years, bureaucrats have justified exemptions from work requirements that are inconsistent with federal law. While the federal food stamp statute does exempt certain populations from work requirements, regulations have expanded exemptions beyond the statutory framework. 19-20 For example, the food stamp statute exempts “a parent or other member of a household with responsibility for a dependent child.” 21 But President Clinton’s FNS issued rules that unlawfully broadened this exemption, allowing it to be applied to able-bodied adults regardless of whether they are parents or caretakers. 22 Able-bodied adults could be exempt from work requirements simply by “residing in a household” with a household member who is under age 18. 23 This conflicts with federal statute, which limits the exemption to individuals “with responsibility for a dependent child.” 24 The Clinton-era rule has allowed able-bodied adults who live with siblings younger than 18 to be exempt from the work requirement, despite the statute specifically limiting the exemption to parents and responsible caretakers. 25 The One, Big, Beautiful Bill made clear that an able-bodied individual may only be exempt from work requirements if they are a parent or a household member with responsibility for a dependent child under 14 years of age. 26 USDA should eliminate the unlawful “residing in a household” exemption to help move tens of thousands of able-bodied adults from welfare to work. USDA should restore the secretary’s discretion to reject state waiver requests Congress intended for waivers of work requirements to be used sparingly, primarily in areas with high unemployment. 27 Federal law gives the Secretary of Agriculture the discretion to waive work requirements at the request of a state agency in areas that have an unemployment rate above 10 percent and those located in a non-contiguous state with an unemployment rate at or above 1.5 times the national unemployment rate. 28 However, FNS regulations have limited the secretary’s discretion by requiring the approval of waivers that are deemed to be “readily approvable.” 29 The regulations state that FNS will approve waivers if an area has a 12-month average unemployment rate over 10 percent, the area has been designated a “labor surplus area,” or the area has a 24-month average unemployment rate that’s greater than the national average by 20 percent. 30 This flies in the face of congressional intent. If Congress had wanted to make approval of these waivers mandatory, they would have done so. Fortunately, in the One, Big, Beautiful Bill, Congress reaffirmed that the approval of work requirement waivers is discretionary. 31 FNS regulations should be updated to remove this mandate and reflect that waivers are discretionary, not “readily approvable.” Any future waivers must meet the requirements of the One, Big, Beautiful bill. Under the One, Big, Beautiful Bill, FNS may now only approve work requirement waivers if an area has an unemployment rate above 10 percent or is located in a non-contiguous state with an unemployment rate at or above 1.5 times the national unemployment rate. 32 FNS should reject any future waivers that do not satisfy these standards. The Bottom Line: USDA should strengthen food stamp work requirements by eliminating unlawful exemptions and restoring the secretary’s discretion to reject waiver requests. The One, Big, Beautiful Bill closed loopholes that states have used to circumvent work requirements. USDA should now align FNS regulations with the new law by removing unlawful exemptions to work requirements and restoring the secretary’s discretion to deny waivers. USDA has already signaled that it would terminate existing waivers that do not align with the requirements of the One, Big, Beautiful bill. 33 Work requirements are a proven way to help people escape dependency. Strengthening work requirements will help put more able-bodied adults on welfare on a path to self-sufficiency. title: Private Generosity, Public Impact: How the New Federal Tax Credit Scholarship Program Is the Next Chapter of Educational Freedom
content: Private Generosity, Public Impact: How the New Federal Tax Credit Scholarship Program Is the Next Chapter of Educational Freedom January 22, 2026 BY Jonathan Bain SHARE DOWNLOAD PAPER [PDF] Issues Education Reform Students’ Right to Know: How States Across the Country Have Empowered Students to Choose Successful Pathways November 2, 2023 How Florida is Leading the Nation in Higher Education March 14, 2022 Knowledge Is Power: Party Affiliation Gives Voters the Signal They Need in School Board Elections February 16, 2024 STOP RIGHT THERE!
